title: Romans Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is described as a servant of Jesus Christ and called to be an apostle in Romans 1:1?
options: Paul
Peter
John
James
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: Romans 1:1 states that Paul is a servant of Jesus Christ and called to be an apostle.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:3, Jesus Christ was made from the seed of whom according to the flesh?
options: David
Abraham
Moses
Noah
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Romans 1:3 says Jesus Christ was made of the seed of David according to the flesh.

questions.question: Romans 1:4 declares Jesus Christ to be the Son of God by what event?
options: His resurrection from the dead
His birth in Bethlehem
His baptism by John
His miracles
questions.correctAnswer: His resurrection from the dead
questions.explanation: Romans 1:4 declares Jesus as the Son of God by the resurrection from the dead.

questions.question: Who does Romans 1:7 say are called to be saints?
options: All in Rome
All Jews
All Greeks
All Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: All in Rome
questions.explanation: Romans 1:7 addresses all that be in Rome, called to be saints.

questions.question: In Romans 1:8, Paul thanks God for whose faith being spoken of throughout the whole world?
options: The believers in Rome
The apostles
The Jews
The Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The believers in Rome
questions.explanation: Romans 1:8 shows Paul thanking God for the faith of the believers in Rome.

questions.question: Romans 1:9 mentions Paul serving God with what part of himself in the gospel of His Son?
options: Spirit
Body
Mind
Heart
questions.correctAnswer: Spirit
questions.explanation: Romans 1:9 says Paul serves God with his spirit in the gospel of His Son.

questions.question: What does Paul desire to impart to the believers in Rome according to Romans 1:11?
options: Some spiritual gift
Wealth and riches
Political power
Military strength
questions.correctAnswer: Some spiritual gift
questions.explanation: Romans 1:11 states Paul longs to impart some spiritual gift to the believers in Rome.

questions.question: Romans 1:14 says Paul is a debtor to which groups?
options: Greeks and Barbarians
Romans only
Jews only
Egyptians and Persians
questions.correctAnswer: Greeks and Barbarians
questions.explanation: Romans 1:14 says Paul is debtor to Greeks and Barbarians, wise and unwise.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:16, Paul is not ashamed of what?
options: The gospel of Christ
His own writings
The law of Moses
His heritage
questions.correctAnswer: The gospel of Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 1:16 states Paul is not ashamed of the gospel of Christ.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 1:17 says the just shall live by faith.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 1:17 quotes 'The just shall live by faith,' confirming it is true.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 1:20 teaches that God’s invisible qualities have been clearly seen since the creation of the world.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 1:20 explains that God’s invisible things are clearly seen from the creation of the world.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 1:21, people glorified God and were thankful when they knew Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 1:21 states that when people knew God, they did not glorify Him or give thanks.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 1:23 says people changed the glory of the uncorruptible God into an image made like to ________.
options: corruptible man
angels
fire
lightning
questions.correctAnswer: corruptible man
questions.explanation: Romans 1:23 says they changed God's glory into an image made like corruptible man.

questions.question: What did God give them up to according to Romans 1:24?
options: Uncleanness
Poverty
War
Disease
questions.correctAnswer: Uncleanness
questions.explanation: Romans 1:24 states God gave them up to uncleanness through lusts of their hearts.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:32, what do those who commit unrighteous things have pleasure in?
options: Others who do them
Wealth
Fame
Peace
questions.correctAnswer: Others who do them
questions.explanation: Romans 1:32 states those who commit unrighteous acts have pleasure in others who do the same.

medium.title: Romans Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about the power of the gospel. Based on Romans 1, what biblical truth would you share about the gospel's effect?
options: The gospel is the power of God unto salvation for everyone who believes
The gospel is only for the Jewish people
The gospel is a suggestion for righteous living
The gospel is a secret message only for apostles
questions.correctAnswer: The gospel is the power of God unto salvation for everyone who believes
questions.explanation: Romans 1:16 states that the gospel is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, both Jew and Greek. This underscores the gospel's universal and salvific power.

questions.question: How does Romans 1 teach us about the importance of faith in the Christian life?
options: The just shall live by faith, revealing the righteousness of God
Faith is only necessary for the apostles
Faith is less important than works
Faith is a vague feeling with no clear purpose
questions.correctAnswer: The just shall live by faith, revealing the righteousness of God
questions.explanation: Romans 1:17 explains that righteousness from God is revealed from faith to faith, quoting 'The just shall live by faith.' This highlights faith as foundational for righteous living.

questions.question: What biblical principle about prayer and fellowship can we learn from Paul's desire to visit the believers in Rome?
options: Paul wished to impart spiritual gifts and be comforted by mutual faith
Paul wanted to judge the believers in Rome
Paul avoided fellowship to focus on his own work
Paul only prayed for them once
questions.correctAnswer: Paul wished to impart spiritual gifts and be comforted by mutual faith
questions.explanation: Romans 1:11-12 shows Paul longed to visit so he could share spiritual gifts and be mutually comforted by their shared faith, emphasizing the value of fellowship and prayer.

questions.question: According to Romans 1, what should be our attitude towards sharing the gospel with others?
options: Be ready and eager to preach the gospel to all people
Only share the gospel with close friends
Avoid preaching to those of different cultures
Preach only when forced to do so
questions.correctAnswer: Be ready and eager to preach the gospel to all people
questions.explanation: Romans 1:14-15 expresses Paul's readiness to preach to Greeks, Barbarians, wise and unwise, including those in Rome, teaching us to be eager and inclusive in evangelism.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to exchange gratitude for God with empty worship. What warning from Romans 1 would you share?
options: Those who do not glorify God become vain in imaginations and darkened in heart
It is acceptable to worship created things
Thankfulness is optional for believers
God ignores how we worship Him
questions.correctAnswer: Those who do not glorify God become vain in imaginations and darkened in heart
questions.explanation: Romans 1:21-22 teaches that failing to honor God leads to foolishness and darkened hearts, warning believers to keep gratitude and true worship central.

questions.question: How does Romans 1 describe God's response to those who reject His truth and live unrighteously?
options: God gives them up to their sinful desires and reprobate minds
God immediately removes them from the earth
God ignores their behavior
God rewards their freedom
questions.correctAnswer: God gives them up to their sinful desires and reprobate minds
questions.explanation: Romans 1:24, 26-28 show that God allows people to follow their sinful lusts and a depraved mind when they reject Him, illustrating the consequences of persistent rebellion.

questions.question: What does Romans 1 teach about the relationship between knowing God and living a thankful life?
options: Knowing God should lead to glorifying and giving thanks to Him
Knowing God has no effect on thankfulness
Thankfulness is unrelated to spiritual knowledge
Glorifying God is only for prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing God should lead to glorifying and giving thanks to Him
questions.explanation: Romans 1:21 explains that when people knew God, they failed to glorify and thank Him, resulting in spiritual darkness, emphasizing the importance of gratitude in faith.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 1, Paul thanked God for the faith of the believers in Rome and prayed for them continually.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 1:8-9 shows Paul giving thanks for the Roman believers' faith and making mention of them always in his prayers, demonstrating the importance of intercessory prayer.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 1 teaches that the gospel should be shared only with people who are wise and educated.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 1:14 says Paul is a debtor to both the wise and unwise, Greeks and Barbarians, indicating the gospel is for all people regardless of status or education.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 1 teaches that the invisible things of God, even his eternal power and Godhead, are clearly seen by the things that are _____.
options: made
heard
spoken
imagined
questions.correctAnswer: made
questions.explanation: Romans 1:20 explains that God's invisible attributes are understood by observing the things that are made, showing God's power and divine nature in creation.

questions.question: How does Romans 1 instruct believers to respond to the reality of God's judgment on unrighteousness?
options: Recognize the seriousness of sin and live in obedience and faith
Ignore God's judgment because grace covers all
Accept unrighteousness as normal
Judge others harshly without self-examination
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize the seriousness of sin and live in obedience and faith
questions.explanation: Romans 1:18, 32 warn about God's wrath against unrighteousness and the judgment on those who persist in sin, calling believers to faith and obedience.

questions.question: Based on Romans 1, what is the foundational reason for Paul’s apostleship and mission?
options: To bring obedience to the faith among all nations for the name of Jesus Christ
To gain personal fame and wealth
To separate from all gentile peoples
To establish new laws for believers
questions.correctAnswer: To bring obedience to the faith among all nations for the name of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 1:1-5 states Paul was called to apostleship to bring obedience to faith among all nations, highlighting evangelism and faith obedience as his mission.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and gratitude can we learn from Romans 1 regarding how people can become foolish?
options: Professing wisdom without glorifying God leads to becoming fools
Pride leads to increased understanding
Gratitude is not necessary for wisdom
Foolishness is unrelated to spiritual devotion
questions.correctAnswer: Professing wisdom without glorifying God leads to becoming fools
questions.explanation: Romans 1:22 teaches that although people claim to be wise, failing to honor God makes them fools, underscoring humility and gratitude in spiritual growth.

questions.question: A believer is seeking encouragement to persevere in prayer for fellow Christians. What example from Romans 1 would you share?
options: Paul constantly prayed without ceasing for the believers in Rome
Paul prayed only when with the believers
Paul stopped praying when he was far away
Paul prayed only for himself
questions.correctAnswer: Paul constantly prayed without ceasing for the believers in Rome
questions.explanation: Romans 1:9 shows Paul serving God with his spirit in the gospel and making mention of the believers always in his prayers, encouraging persistence in prayer.

questions.question: What does Romans 1 reveal about the consequence of exchanging the truth of God for a lie in worship?
options: God gave them up to dishonorable passions and vile affections
They were immediately forgiven without consequence
God rewarded their worship of creation
There is no consequence for false worship
questions.correctAnswer: God gave them up to dishonorable passions and vile affections
questions.explanation: Romans 1:25-27 explains that exchanging God's truth for lies led God to give people over to uncleanness and vile affections, showing serious consequences for idolatry.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 1.

questions.question: In Romans 1:3-4, Paul describes Jesus Christ as "made of the seed of David according to the flesh" and "declared to be the Son of God with power." How does this dual description reflect a typological connection between the Old Testament Davidic covenant and the New Testament resurrection?
options: It shows Jesus fulfilling the messianic promise through both human lineage and divine resurrection power
It emphasizes Jesus as purely divine without human ancestry
It rejects the Old Testament covenant in favor of a new law
It highlights a contrast between Jesus and David, denying any connection
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Jesus fulfilling the messianic promise through both human lineage and divine resurrection power
questions.explanation: Romans 1:3-4 connects Jesus to David's lineage (Old Testament promise) and affirms his divine sonship by resurrection power, fulfilling messianic expectations.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by saying he is "a debtor both to the Greeks, and to the Barbarians; both to the wise, and to the unwise" in Romans 1:14, and how does this reflect the mission strategy of early Christianity?
options: Paul feels obligated to preach the gospel universally, transcending cultural and intellectual boundaries
Paul is only responsible for preaching to the Jews
Paul limits his mission only to the wise Greeks
Paul rejects preaching to the Barbarians due to cultural differences
questions.correctAnswer: Paul feels obligated to preach the gospel universally, transcending cultural and intellectual boundaries
questions.explanation: Romans 1:14 emphasizes Paul's commitment to spread the gospel to all peoples, reflecting early Christian mission's inclusive nature across diverse cultures.

questions.question: In the literary structure of Romans 1:16-17, how does Paul use parallelism to emphasize the power and righteousness of the gospel?
options: By stating the gospel is the power of God unto salvation and that the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith
By contrasting the gospel with human wisdom and power
By repeating the word 'faith' without context
By focusing solely on the Jewish audience's salvation
questions.correctAnswer: By stating the gospel is the power of God unto salvation and that the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith
questions.explanation: Romans 1:16-17 uses parallelism to connect the gospel's power with righteousness revealed progressively through faith, reinforcing theological themes.

questions.question: The phrase "The just shall live by faith" in Romans 1:17 is a direct quotation from which Old Testament book, and what is the significance of this intertextual connection?
options: Habakkuk, highlighting continuity between prophetic faith and Christian doctrine
Psalms, emphasizing worship and praise
Genesis, focusing on creation theology
Isaiah, stressing judgment themes
questions.correctAnswer: Habakkuk, highlighting continuity between prophetic faith and Christian doctrine
questions.explanation: Romans 1:17 quotes Habakkuk 2:4, linking Old Testament prophetic faith with the Christian emphasis on faith as foundational for righteousness.

questions.question: How does the concept of "wrath of God" in Romans 1:18 relate to the ancient Near Eastern understanding of divine justice and covenantal retribution?
options: It reflects the idea that God's anger is a response to covenant violation and moral unrighteousness
It signifies arbitrary punishment without cause
It suggests that wrath is unrelated to human behavior
It denies any connection between God and human justice
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the idea that God's anger is a response to covenant violation and moral unrighteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 1:18 portrays God's wrath as just retribution for ungodliness and unrighteousness, consistent with covenantal principles in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: In Romans 1:20, what is the theological significance of the claim that God's invisible attributes have been clearly seen since creation, and how does this relate to natural theology?
options: It supports the idea that God's existence and power are evident through nature, leaving humanity without excuse
It denies any possibility of knowing God through creation
It suggests that only special revelation can reveal God
It limits God's attributes to human imagination
questions.correctAnswer: It supports the idea that God's existence and power are evident through nature, leaving humanity without excuse
questions.explanation: Romans 1:20 affirms natural theology by asserting that God's eternal power and divine nature are manifest in creation, accountable to all people.

questions.question: Analyze the use of irony in Romans 1:22 where those "professing themselves to be wise" became fools. How does this statement critique human wisdom in light of divine revelation?
options: It ironically exposes human pride and folly when rejecting God's truth despite claiming wisdom
It praises human wisdom as superior to divine truth
It suggests that wisdom is irrelevant to understanding God
It condemns foolishness in others but not in the self
questions.correctAnswer: It ironically exposes human pride and folly when rejecting God's truth despite claiming wisdom
questions.explanation: Romans 1:22 uses irony to highlight the discrepancy between human self-professed wisdom and actual foolishness in rejecting God’s revelation.

questions.question: How does the idol worship described in Romans 1:23 reflect the cultural and religious syncretism of the ancient Roman world?
options: People exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling corruptible creatures, blending pagan practices
It describes exclusive worship of the one true God without images
It condemns the use of any physical objects in worship irrespective of form
It supports animal worship as a divine mandate
questions.correctAnswer: People exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling corruptible creatures, blending pagan practices
questions.explanation: Romans 1:23 critiques the prevalent Roman religious syncretism where divine worship was mixed with idolatrous images of animals and humans.

questions.question: In Romans 1:25, Paul states that those who worship the creature more than the Creator "changed the truth of God into a lie." What is the significance of this statement in the context of Second Temple Jewish monotheism?
options: It condemns idolatry as a fundamental distortion of God’s revealed truth
It encourages worship of nature alongside God
It denies the existence of God as Creator
It promotes polytheism as an acceptable practice
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns idolatry as a fundamental distortion of God’s revealed truth
questions.explanation: Romans 1:25 reflects Second Temple Judaism’s strong monotheistic stance against idolatry, affirming worship must be directed to God alone.

questions.question: Romans 1:26-27 describes God "giving them up" to vile affections and unnatural relations. How does this passage connect with ancient cultural understandings of moral order and divine judgment?
options: It illustrates that violating natural moral order leads to divine abandonment as judgment
It endorses these relationships as culturally normative
It suggests that divine judgment is unrelated to moral behavior
It promotes tolerance without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates that violating natural moral order leads to divine abandonment as judgment
questions.explanation: Romans 1:26-27 reflects the ancient view that moral perversions provoke God to withdraw restraint, resulting in judgment consistent with cultural norms.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated phrase "God gave them up" in Romans 1:24, 26, and 28 in terms of literary structure and theological emphasis?
options: It forms a triadic literary device emphasizing divine judicial abandonment due to persistent sin
It indicates God’s approval of sinful behavior
It is a random phrase without thematic importance
It shows God’s direct infliction of sin upon people
questions.correctAnswer: It forms a triadic literary device emphasizing divine judicial abandonment due to persistent sin
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase in Romans 1 underscores a chiastic structure highlighting God's judicial decision to give sinners over to their desires.

questions.question: In Romans 1:18-32, Paul catalogs various sins and behaviors. How does this list function rhetorically in Paul's argument about human sinfulness and need for salvation?
options: It serves as a comprehensive indictment of humanity's universal sinfulness, justifying the gospel’s necessity
It praises human moral achievements
It limits sinfulness to a specific ethnic group
It denies the existence of sin altogether
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a comprehensive indictment of humanity's universal sinfulness, justifying the gospel’s necessity
questions.explanation: Romans 1:18-32 rhetorically portrays the depth of human rebellion to emphasize the need for salvation through the gospel.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 1:9-10, Paul prays continually for the Roman believers and desires to visit them if it is God's will.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 1:9-10 shows Paul's persistent prayer for the Roman church and his wish to visit them contingent on God's will.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 1:5 says Paul received grace and apostleship for obedience to the faith among all nations, for ________ name.
options: his
their
our
the
questions.correctAnswer: his
questions.explanation: Romans 1:5 states that grace and apostleship were received for obedience to the faith among all nations, for his (Jesus Christ's) name.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:8, what is the global reputation of the faith of the Roman believers, and how does this reflect early Christian expansion?
options: Their faith is spoken of throughout the whole world
Their faith is only known locally in Rome
Their faith is criticized worldwide
Their faith is secret and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: Their faith is spoken of throughout the whole world
questions.explanation: Romans 1:8 reveals that the faith of Roman Christians had gained widespread recognition, illustrating early Christianity's rapid expansion.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:3-4, what two key aspects define Jesus Christ in relation to God's plan?
options: He was made of the seed of David according to the flesh and declared the Son of God by resurrection
He was a prophet and teacher in Israel
He was an angel sent to save Israel
He was the firstborn of all creation and a priest forever
questions.correctAnswer: He was made of the seed of David according to the flesh and declared the Son of God by resurrection
questions.explanation: Romans 1:3 speaks of Christ's human lineage from David, affirming His messianic fulfillment, and verse 4 declares His divine status by the power of the resurrection, consistent with Old Testament prophecies like 2 Samuel 7:12-16 and Psalm 16:10, and New Testament affirmations in Acts 13:33 and Hebrews 1:5.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Paul's apostleship as described in Romans 1:5?
options: For obedience to the faith among all nations
To establish a new law for Israel
To gather wealth for the church
To preach only to the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: For obedience to the faith among all nations
questions.explanation: Paul states in Romans 1:5 that his apostleship is granted to bring about obedience to the faith among all nations, highlighting the universal scope of the gospel, which aligns with the Great Commission in Matthew 28:19 and the inclusion of Gentiles in Ephesians 2:11-22.

questions.question: In Romans 1:16, why does Paul say he is not ashamed of the gospel of Christ?
options: Because it is the power of God unto salvation to everyone who believes
Because it guarantees earthly riches
Because it excludes the Gentiles
Because it is a hidden mystery
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is the power of God unto salvation to everyone who believes
questions.explanation: Romans 1:16 explains that the gospel is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, both Jew and Greek, emphasizing the gospel’s efficacy and universality, consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:18 and John 3:16.

questions.question: What does Romans 1:17 declare about the righteousness of God?
options: It is revealed from faith to faith
It is earned by works
It is only for the Jewish people
It is a future gift after judgment
questions.correctAnswer: It is revealed from faith to faith
questions.explanation: Romans 1:17 states the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith, meaning it is accessed and lived by faith, echoing Habakkuk 2:4 and reinforcing justification by faith as taught in Galatians 3:11 and Hebrews 10:38.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:18, what is revealed from heaven against ungodliness and unrighteousness?
options: The wrath of God
The mercy of God
The love of God
The patience of God
questions.correctAnswer: The wrath of God
questions.explanation: Romans 1:18 reveals the wrath of God from heaven against ungodliness and unrighteousness, indicating divine judgment on sin, consistent with Psalm 7:11, Nahum 1:2, and Revelation 6:16-17.

questions.question: What does Romans 1:20 say about God's invisible attributes?
options: They are clearly seen from the creation of the world by the things that are made
They are hidden and unknowable
They are only revealed in the law
They are only understood by the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They are clearly seen from the creation of the world by the things that are made
questions.explanation: Romans 1:20 teaches that God’s invisible attributes, such as eternal power and divine nature, are clearly perceived through creation, leaving humanity without excuse, paralleling Psalm 19:1-4 and Job 12:7-10.

questions.question: What consequence does Romans 1:24 describe for those who reject God?
options: God gave them up to uncleanness through the lusts of their own hearts
God delivered them with miracles
God granted them peace
God sent angels to guide them
questions.correctAnswer: God gave them up to uncleanness through the lusts of their own hearts
questions.explanation: Romans 1:24 explains that God gave those who rejected Him over to uncleanness, a form of judgment involving moral impurity, consistent with Old Testament examples like Psalm 81:11-12 and New Testament warnings in 2 Thessalonians 2:10-12.

questions.question: In Romans 1:25, what did people exchange the truth of God for?
options: A lie, worshipping the creature rather than the Creator
Idols made of gold only
The law of Moses
Philosophical teachings
questions.correctAnswer: A lie, worshipping the creature rather than the Creator
questions.explanation: Romans 1:25 states that people exchanged God’s truth for a lie by worshipping created things instead of the Creator, reflecting idolatry condemned in Exodus 20:3-5 and Psalm 106:20.

questions.question: What specific unnatural behaviors does Romans 1:26-27 mention as consequences of rejecting God?
options: Women and men exchanging natural relations for unnatural ones
Only women committing adultery
Men becoming prophets
All people becoming silent
questions.correctAnswer: Women and men exchanging natural relations for unnatural ones
questions.explanation: Romans 1:26-27 refers to both women and men abandoning natural sexual relations for unnatural acts, which is described as a judgment from God, linking to Leviticus 18:22 and Judges 19:22-25.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:28, what did God give them over to because they did not retain Him in knowledge?
options: A reprobate mind to do things not fitting
A spirit of prophecy
A renewed heart
A covenant of peace
questions.correctAnswer: A reprobate mind to do things not fitting
questions.explanation: Romans 1:28 says that God gave those who rejected Him a reprobate mind, allowing them to do things inappropriate, which aligns with Isaiah 66:4 and Jeremiah 6:15 about hardness of heart.

questions.question: What list of sins does Paul give in Romans 1:29-31 as evidence of ungodliness?
options: Unrighteousness, fornication, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness, envy, murder, deceit, pride, disobedience
Only theft and lying
Sabbath breaking and idolatry only
Faith and hope
questions.correctAnswer: Unrighteousness, fornication, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness, envy, murder, deceit, pride, disobedience
questions.explanation: Romans 1:29-31 lists a broad spectrum of sins demonstrating humanity’s fallen condition, matching similar lists in Galatians 5:19-21 and 2 Timothy 3:2-5.

questions.question: What does Romans 1:32 say about those who commit such sins and those who approve of them?
options: They know God's judgment and are worthy of death but continue and approve of others who do the same
They will be forgiven without repentance
They are excluded from judgment
They will be honored among men
questions.correctAnswer: They know God's judgment and are worthy of death but continue and approve of others who do the same
questions.explanation: Romans 1:32 highlights that sinners are aware of God's righteous judgment but not only persist in sin but also encourage others, consistent with Ezekiel 18:4 and Proverbs 1:32.

questions.question: In Romans 1:1-2, Paul describes himself as separated unto what purpose?
options: The gospel of God
The law of Moses
The temple service
The teachings of the rabbis
questions.correctAnswer: The gospel of God
questions.explanation: Romans 1:1-2 states Paul is separated unto the gospel of God promised through the prophets, emphasizing his divine calling to proclaim salvation as foretold in Isaiah 52:7 and Jeremiah 31:31.

questions.question: What does Paul express in Romans 1:9-10 about his prayers for the Roman believers?
options: That he makes mention of them always and longs to visit them if God wills
That he has forgotten them
That he doubts their faith
That he wants them to send financial aid
questions.correctAnswer: That he makes mention of them always and longs to visit them if God wills
questions.explanation: Romans 1:9-10 shows Paul’s continual prayers for the Romans and desire to visit them, reflecting his pastoral concern and submission to God’s will, correlating with 1 Thessalonians 1:2 and Philippians 1:3-5.

questions.question: According to Romans 1:6-7, how does Paul describe the Roman believers?
options: Beloved of God and called to be saints
Enemies of the gospel
Unworthy sinners
Only Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Beloved of God and called to be saints
questions.explanation: Romans 1:6-7 refers to the Roman believers as beloved of God and called saints, affirming their identity in Christ consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:2 and Ephesians 1:1-2.
